Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Asteroseismology of subdwarf B stars as representatives of high-temperature physics and horizontal branch stellar cores.
Award.AbstractNarration:
The researchers will analyze data already in hand from the Kepler satellite of sdB stars, obtain new ground-based high-speed multicolor observations of these stars to supplement the observations for further analysis, and generate perturbed atmospheric models to interpret all the observations. Finally, they will generate evolutionary models which match the data and test the physics within sdB stars. Subdwarf B (sdB) stars are horizontal branch stars that are low mass white dwarf precursors. They are envelope-stripped objects which are very blue and UV bright yet retain sufficient mass to be core helium burning stars. Their progenitors are stars like our sun and are responsible for the UV excess detected in some elliptical galaxies and globular clusters.

Undergraduate students will take part in the proposed research program by obtaining, reducing and analyzing data and then disseminating results at conferences and in papers. The PI will work to increase the participation of underrepresented minorities in STEM fields. Additionally, the PI and his team (including undergraduate students) will collaborate with scientists on a national level (including in Iowa and with the Whole Earth Telescope), and international level (including N. Ireland, Belgium and Poland, and the Nordic Optical Telescope).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of our work is to understand the internal structure
and processes occurring within hot compact stars which get their energy
from helium fusion. These stars are interesting for many reasons: our Sun
will eventually become one of these stars and through their pulsations
(vibrations) they allow us to study conditions we cannot currently
produce in Earth-bound labs. Those conditions include extreme hot
and high-pressure environments where a diffusion occurs which floats
elements like iron and sinks elements like helium. And of course we also
get constraints (reaction cross-sections) on helium fusion, which has been
of interest since the 1980s.
Our understanding of these stars comes from models, but models have to include
appropriate physics. How that physics is included is based on observations
and prior to the Kepler space telescope, those observations were extremely
limited. During this grant, we examined Kepler data for several of these
interesting stars and we were able to provide lots of parameters for
models to fit. Because of our work, the models can no longer match our
observations. This is a good thing, as it means the models need to
incorporate additional physics, and that's how we learn and advance
science.
One example is that we have learned that these stars, while compact and
under high gravity, are not as stratified as pre-Kepler models predicted.
Original assumptions were that sharp chemical boundaries would occur,
which cause reflective boundaries for vibrations. We do not observe those
reflections, meaning the boundaries are softer and more diffuse. This
requires updates to the models to explain how the boundaries diffuse.
Because of our work, models will require substantial updates, meaning
many paths of investigation and additional physics will be required.
We consider this to be a huge success as that is what observations
are for.
We also used our work as an opportunity for undergraduate students
to participate in science research. During this grant, nine students
worked with Kepler telescope data, several continuing on to graduate
programs in astronomy. Most students were able to present their results
at science conferences, publish papers in professional journals (often
as contributing authors and on three occasions as first authors), and
interact with our international collaboration. This has provide
valuable experience for these students to help them determine
their future career paths.
